Elsie is very grateful to SMT and the income has enabled her meet her family expenses, especially school fees and loan repayment.

loans.use: Elsie would like to further diversify her business by adding a larger assortment of jewelry.

loans.name: Hassanatu

texts.en: Hassanatu is married with three children and sells local food (a rice-and-cassava-leaves dish) in Kabala town in Sierra Leone.  She sells other items beside the main food business.  With a previous loans she increased her stock of ingredients and the profit has enabled her to support her two school-going children.  She makes a good profit from the restaurant, but she needs more capital to meet the increased demand for food in the community.

loans.use: Hassanatu would like to increase her stock of ingredients.

loans.name: Alhaji

texts.en: Alhaji B. is a young man who is trying to improve his livelihood through business.  At the age of 25, Alhaji is managing a general store in Kabala town of Sierra Leone.   His previous loan from SMT diversified his business and he was able to construct the kiosk for the shop from the profit.   With his profits, he supports his parents.  He is requesting an additional loan to expand the business further.

loans.use: Alhaji is a young entrepreneur who would like to strengthen his business further so that he can continue to care for his parents.

loans.name: Alhaji

texts.en: Alhaji B. is a young man trying to improve his livelihood through business.  At the age of 25, Alhaji is managing a general store in Kabala town of Sierra Leone.   His previous loan from SMT diversified his business and he was able to construct the kiosk for the shop from the profit.   With his profits, he supports his parents.  He is requesting an additional loan to expand the business further.

loans.use: Alhaji is a young entrepreneur who would like to strengthen his business further so that he can continue to care for his parents.

loans.name: Alhaji

texts.en: Alhaji B. is a young man trying to improve his livelihood through business.  At the age of 25, Alhaji is managing a general store in Kabala town of Sierra Leone.   His previous loan from SMT diversified his business and he was able to construct the kiosk for the shop from the profit.   With his profits, he supports his parents.  He is requesting for an additional loan to expand the business further.

loans.use: Alhaji is a young entrepreneur who would like to strengthen his business further so that he can continue to care for his parents.

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en: Kadiatu is 45 years old and married with two children.  Kadiatu is well-known in her community for her fish sales.  There is high demand for fish in Kabala, and for Kadiatu to make greater profits, she is requesting a loan to expand her business.  With the profit, she is able to support her family, especially her husband who has been unemployed for the last two years.

loans.use: Kadiatu would like to increase the amount of fish she is able to buy and sell  within her community.

loans.name: Raka

texts.en:
Raka is married and has a child.

He has been running his business for 15 years, even during the war, but at a very small scale. With his previous loans from SMT, he diversified the business. He sells clothes and sandals for men, women and children. With the profit, he is able to improve his living standard and send his child to school. Raka’s customers demand new fashion in their clothes and he is therefore requesting for a loan to meet his customers demands and expand his stock.

loans.use: He would like to diversify his stock by adding in some of the latest fashions demanded by his customers.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is 27 years old and married with two children.  He repairs motorbikes in Dogolaia village, in Kabala town.  With the savings from the income, he received a loan from SMT and purchased a motorbike that provides transport services in the village. With the profit from the first motorbike and another loan from SMT, Ibrahim purchased another motorbike.  The bikes provide transport to and from Kabala town and other surrounding villages.  Ibrahim's enterprise has solved transportation problems in the community.  In order to continue serving the community, Ibrahim's requesting another loan to purchase another motorbike.

loans.use: Ibrahim has used creativity and innovation to create a business that serves the transportation needs of his community.  He seeks a loan to help him build that great idea into a sustainable business.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed is a young man who is planning to live an independent life.  He believes in small enterprise as the fastest way to improve his life.  He started his general store by selling in the streets; after his first loan from SMT, he rented a small shop and has increased his stock with the subsequent loans.  He now requests another loan to further expand his business.  Mohamed is very honest and prompt in repaying his loans.

loans.use: To invest in his business now that he is primed and ready for growth.

loans.name: Mirna Guadalupe

texts.es:
Unfortunately, Mirna Guadalupe’s husband was terminated from his job over three years ago. And being that they had no other source of income and he couldn’t find a new job, Mirna and her husband, with some money he got from his unemployment compensation, started a small candy store. Fortunately, the candies were a success in their neighborhood. That was why shortly after Mirna’s husband got a new job, she took over the store. Mirna’s mother-in-law lent her a small locale so that they could better establish the business. After that, she introduced more variety to her products such as bread, groceries and beverages, among other things.

Sadly, however, several clients begin asking to borrow credit, and Mirna, with all the will to generate sales, would accept their offers but many people did not follow through. Now Mirna has neither sufficient merchandise nor the money to restock. That is why she is requesting a loan of $925, which she is willing to repay in 6 months. With that money, Mirna will be able to buy more merchandise to keep her business running and recover from that problem. “I plan to sell to my debtors for cash only and not by credit,” she commented. With your help, Mirna will be able to progress.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

Desafortunadamente hace más de tres años que despidieron de su trabajo al esposo de Mirna Guadalupe. Y puesto que no tenían otra fuente de ingreso y no podía conseguir un trabajo nuevo Mirna y su esposo, con un poco de dinero que le dieron de su liquidación fue como comenzaron a hacer un pequeño negocio de venta de dulces. Afortunadamente, los dulces comenzaron a tener éxito en su colonia, fue por eso que poco tiempo después de que el esposo de Mirna consiguiera trabajo, Mirna se encargó del local. Y la suegra de Mirna le prestó un pequeño local para poder establecer mejor el negocio. Fue ahí como comenzó a introducir un poco más de variedad en sus productos como; pan, abarrotes, refrescos entre otras cosas.

Sin embargo desgraciadamente, varios clientes le comenzaron a pedir prestado, y Mirna con todas las ganas de vender accedía venderle los productos a crédito, y muchos le quedaron mal. Ahora Mirna no tiene productos suficientes, y tampoco tiene dinero para resurtir. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $925 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Mirna podrá comprar más mercancía para darle movimiento y así recuperarse de este problema. “Sólo pienso vender de contado a sus deudores y no fiar a la clientela” comentó. Con tu ayuda Mirna podrá salir adelante.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to stock her business

loans.name: Seray

texts.en: Seray B. is 35 years old and married, with five children.  Her husband has an irregular salary and could not meet the family expenses.  She started the business to support the family but the business is at a very small scale due to lack of capital.  Seray will complete her current loan repayment in January and would like to take another loan to further expand the business.

loans.use: Seray runs a small general store and would like to expand the business so she can better care for her family.

loans.name: Alphajor

texts.en:
Alphajor S. has a very creative enterprise. He has two bikes that he rents to those wishing to transport themselves or goods to various locations in Koinadugu village. He said there is a high demand for the service, especially on market days, and is requesting a loan so he may purchase another motorbike.

With the income he feels capable of providing his family needs, and is grateful for SMT's loan activity. Married with 4 children, he said he has a foundation for his children’s education.

loans.use: He would like to purchase another motorbike to meet the demand for transportation on market days.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama is married with four children, and has to work hard to meet some of her children's expenses.

She trades palm oil and cow milk. She has two cows, and she also buys the milk from neighbors to sell at the market. Mariama lives in a predominately Muslim community where milk is one of the main foods; there is high demand for milk in the area. Mariama is requesting a loan to increase her stock of milk.

loans.use: Mariama wants to increase the amount of milk she is able to buy and sell within her community.

loans.name: Reymundo Ricardo

texts.es:
Don Reymundo lives in the Tres Ochenta neighborhood in the capital city of Managua, a neighborhood where poverty is rather evident and all of the inhabitants fight day after day to be able to survive. Such is the case of don Reymundo, whose occupation is repairing shoes and sometimes bags and backpacks. He has 15 years of experience in this line of work. Don Reymundo is 38-years-old, is married, and has 3 children. Two of them are in primary school and one is in secondary school. His wife is a housewife, and he is in charge of providing food for his family. His business of repairing shoes provides him with very little to be able to support his family. This is why he started fixing up his house 3 years ago to rent rooms to young students. Don Reymundo needs this money to construct a bathroom for his guests so he can give them better service. The dream of don Reymundo is to buy an industrial machine to repair shoes, and to start making and selling shoes himself.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Don Reymundo habita en el barrio Tres Ochenta de la Capital Managua, un barrio donde la pobreza es bastante evidente y todos sus pobladores luchan día a día para poder subsistir. Tal es el caso de Don Reymundo cuyo oficio es zapatero y algunas otras veces repara bolsos y mochilas, tiene 15 años dedicandose a esta actividad. Don Reymundo tiene 38 años de edad, es casado y con 3 hijos menores de edad, dos de ellos cursando la escuela primaria y uno la escuela secundaria. Su esposa es ama de casa, él es el encargado de proveer de alimentos a la familia. Su negocio de zapatería le da muy poco para mantener a su familia, es por eso que hace tres años, empezó el acondicionamiento de su vivienda para alquilar cuartos a jovenes estudiantes.Don Reymundo requiere el dinero para construir un servicio higiénico y un baño para sus huespedes para poderles dar un mejor servicio. El sueño de don reymundo es comprarse una máquina industrial para su zapatería, y empezar a elaborar él mismo zapatos y venderlos.

loans.use: Purchase of a bathroom

loans.name: Alusine

texts.en: Forty-five-year-old Alusine B. is married with five children.  He trades foods such as rice, millet, and peanuts.  He purchases them from the villages and sells them wholesale and retail in Kabala town, in Sierra Leone.  With his previous loans, Alusine was able to generate enough profit for his family expenses.  He still plans to expand the business and is therefore requesting another loan for more capital.

loans.use: He would like to increase his business of selling food staple items on wholesale.

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Ana belongs to the Cesar Vallejo community bank, in Heladio Mayta 170, Calleria district, Ucayali. She is 61 years old, a mother of six children, 5 of whom have left home and one still lives with Ana. She is married, and her husband is retired. With the first loan of S/. 300 which she received from Manuela Ramos, Ana invested in making clothes. Nowadays, she relies on a small workshop to make clothes, and she also sells sweets. She gets up at 6am to prepare her son’s breakfast and then sets about making her clothes. With the loan of 1000 soles, which will be paid in five months, she will use S/. 300 soles to buy fabric, S/. 400 for sweets and the rest she will put aside as contingency capital. Anna is a good person who feels that working with Manual Ramos gives her a great deal of support economically, she is more independent and says that life is a constant struggle which she must face if she wants to suceed despite all the obstacles.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer

La señora Ana pertenece al Banco Comunal Cesar Vallejo, ubicado en pasaje Heladio Mayta 170, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 61 años y es madre de 6 hijos, 6 de ellos son independientes y uno aún depende de ella. Es casada y su esposo es jubilado. Ana con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la confección de ropas. En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeño taller de confección de ropa, también se dedica a la venta de golosinas. Se levanta a las 6 a.m. para preparar el desayuno de su hijo y esposo y luego se dedica a la confección de sus prendas. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de S/. 300 en telas, S/. 400 en golosinas y el resto del préstamo lo dejará como capital de reserva. Ana está muy bien, siente que trabajando con Manuela Ramos le brinda mucho apoyo en la parte económica, es más independiente y dice que la vida es una lucha constante que hay que seguir si uno desea salir triunfante en todos los obstáculos.

loans.use: To buy fabric and sweets

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata J. is a 30-year-old married mother of four children. 

Fatmata came up with the idea of selling food items in the village where access to these items was difficult. She has now been in business for four years. She sells onions, tomato pest, chicken stocks, etc., and has saved the village women from traveling to either Kabala town or a trading center located 3 kilometers away. With previous loans, she increased her stock and now would like to expand more.

loans.use: She wants to build her business by increasing her stock.

loans.name: Marcos

texts.en:
Marcos is a 54-year-old father who is married and has two children. He has worked in the shipping business and from this, has made enough funds to invest in two of his own businesses. His first business is the sale of construction materials and the second is providing telephone service to people for a fee. Both businesses are run by Marcos and his wife and they share the responsibilities.

With the profits he makes from these two businesses, Marcos wants to invest in buying more bricks, sand, and other construction materials. The demand is always high in the area of construction, yet exceptionally high during these next few months. The construction materials he sells are very scarce and it is hard to meet the demand of the customers.

Marcos is asking for a loan in order to purchase these items, to keep his business running smoothly and to continue to work towards a better life for his family.

loans.use: To buy brick, cement, quicklime, and other construction materials

loans.name: Adilia

texts.es:
Adilia lives in Sabana Grande, a town in Managua City. She is 54 years old and married with 5 children, all of whom are grown-up and have left home. Adilia lives alone with her husband, who is retired and receives a monthly social security pension. Adilia’s job is buying food such as nacatamals (a type of Nicaraguan tamal), curds, meat soups and tripes, which she sells on weekends. Adilia needs money to buy two pigs to feed and fatten and then use for their meat. She wants to concentrate on selling pig meat which is why a percentage of it will be sold and the rest will go into the nacatamals.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer

Doña Adilia habita en la Comarca Sabana Grande, un municipio de la ciudad de Managua. Ella tiene 54 años de edad es casada. Tuvo 5 hijos los cuales son mayores de edad y viven independientes. Doña Adilia solamente vive con su esposo, quien está jubilado y mensualmente recive una pensión por parte del seguro social. Doña Adilia se dedica a la venta de comida: nacatamales, cuajada, sopa de res y mondongo, estas ventas las realiza los fines de semana. Doña Adilia necesita el dinero para comprar 2 cerdos, engordarlos y destazarlos. Quiere dedicarse a la venta de carne de cerdo, es por eso que destinará un porcentaje de esa carne para venta y el otro lo ocupará para hacer los nacatamales.

loans.use: To purchase two pigs, for their meat

loans.name: Angelita

texts.es:
Angelita belongs to the communal bank Virgen de la Natividad, located in Jr. Sinchi Roca Nº 125, Calleria district, Ucayali state. She is 32 years old and is mother to two children. Her husband is a teacher and taxi driver. With her first loan of S/300 that she received from Manuela Ramos Angelita decided to invest in a small store in her home.

Today she has her store, and she gets up at 6:00 am and prepares breakfast for her children and then works in the store until 10:00 pm.

With a loan for S/1800, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will buy 3 sacks of rice, 2 sacks of sugar, 4 cases of oil, 5 cases of milk, vegetables, 2 cases of beer, 10 cases of soda pop, candy, etc.

Angelita is very happy, her business grows every day, and now she can buy many things that the need. Her family is happy for her and she is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for all the support given to her business.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Angelita pertenece al banco comunal Virgen de la Natividad, ubicado en Jr. Sinchi Roca Nº 125, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 32 años y es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad, su esposo es profesor y motocarrista. Angelita con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en una pequeña bodega en su domicilio.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con una bodega. Par ello se levanta a las 6.00 a.m. y prepara el desayuno de sus hijos y el de su esposo y luego atiende la bodega hasta las 10.00 p.m.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,800, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 3 sacos de arroz, 2 sacos de azúcar, 4 cajas de aceite, 5 cajas de leche, verduras, 2 cajas de cerveza, 10 cajas de gaseosas, golosinas, etc.

Angelita está muy feliz, su negocio crece cada día y ahora puede comprarse muchas cosas que tanto deseaba. Su familia está feliz por ella y ella está muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos por todo el apoyo dado para su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase groceries (rice, sugar, oil, milk, etc.)

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en: Mariama M. lives in the Yataya village in Kabala town.  She is 25 years old and married with three children.  Mariama started her business on a small scale three years ago in the homestead.  With the previous loans she expanded the business and was also able to take care of some family expenses.  She is requesting a loan so she can open a small kiosk and expand her stock to provide better service to the people in Yataya village.

loans.use: To expand her stock to attract new customers so that she can one day open a small kiosk of her own.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah K. sells rice in the community.  She purchases husked rice and palm kernels from farmers in the villages and processes them for retail sale. She intends to expand her business and is therefore requesting a loan.

Sarah is 45 years old and she lives in Yataya village Kabala, in Sierra Leone. She is married with four children.

loans.use: Sarah would like to be able to purchase larger quantities of raw materials to process and sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy more utensils, tables, chairs and food for her little restaurant

loans.name: Lilliam Del Socorro

texts.es:
Lilliam lives in Sabana Grande, where many people work in retail. Lilliam is 35 years old, married, with a six-year-old son who attends school. Lilliam and her husband sell fish and seafood such as ray/skate fish fillets, mojarra and pargo, amongst others. These are caught in the waters off some of Nicaragua’s beaches such as Masachapa and el Puerto de Corinto. Some of the produce is sold in their home, and some is sold in markets or on the streets. Lilliam needs this loan due to the current situation in Nicaragua - produce is becoming more expensive and she needs to buy fish and seafood in order to continue rotating her stock and generating a family income.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer

Doña Lilliam habita en la comarca de Sabana Grande, lugar donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican al comercio. Doña Lilliam tiene 35 años, es casada, con un niño de 6 años que asiste a la escuela. Doña Lilliam y su esposo se dedican a la venta de pescados y mariscos como filete de raya, mojarra, pargo, entre otros. Los productos lo adquieren de las costas de algunas playas de Nicaragua como son Masachapa y el Puerto de Corinto, una parte del producto lo venden en su casa, y otra parte se dedican a ofrecerlos en los mercados o venderlos ambulante. Necesita el préstamos ya que debido a la situación por la que pasa el país, el producto se está volviendo más caro, y requiere comprar los pescados y mariscos para seguir rotando su inventario y generando ingresos para su familia.

loans.use: To purchase seafood for her business

loans.name: Fanta

texts.en: Fanta is married with one child.  She is 28 years old and sells palm oil in the village.  She used to sell 3 gallons each day, but with her previous loans her business increased to 15 gallons.  She is requesting for a loan to expand and diversify her business.

loans.use: She would like to add additional items to her stock to diversify and create new business.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: Having spent 15 years selling food in the market of Kabala town in Sierra Leone, Hawa K. has broad experience with what types of food people like most.  She sells mainly rice with cassava leaves and fish sauce, sweet potato leaves with fish or meat, and peanut soup with meat.  Before the loan, she could hardly serve 500 clients a week.  With the previous loans she can now serve 1000 customers per week. Her business and income has increased.  Hawa is requesting a loan to purchase more ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: She needs to purchase her ingredients in bulk so that she can both keep up with demand and maximize her profits.

loans.name: Julia Justina

texts.es:
Miss Julia is 50 years old. She is a single mother of two children, an 18 year old young woman and a 7 year old boy. Miss Julia has a small general store in her house and also sells clothing and cosmetics. Her daughter helps her sell the clothing and cosmetics at the university. She accepts payments in cash or in installments. Thanks to these two activities Miss Julia can support her family and provide an education for her children. The loan she is requesting will be used buy sand, cement, building blocks and iron (metal) to build an additional bedroom so she can provide her children a decent home.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Julia tiene 50 años, es madre soltera de dos hijos, una joven de 18 años y un niño de 7 años. Doña Julia tiene una pequeña pulpería en su casa de habitación y también se dedica a la venta de ropa y cosméticos. Su hija le ayuda colocando ropa y cosméticos en la universidad, sus ventas las realiza al contado y al crédito. Estas dos actividades que doña Julia realiza le ayudan a mantener su hogar, y darles educación a sus hijos. El crédito lo quiere para comprar arena, cemento, bloques y hierros para construir un cuarto de habitación ya que desea darles una vivienda más digna a sus dos hijos.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build a bedroom.

loans.name: Abu

texts.en:
Abu S. is 28 years old and married with 2 children.  He owns a shop in Kabala town; most of the goods are purchased on credit and repayments made to the merchant on a daily basis .  This does not yield good profits for S..  He supplements his income with tailoring, as he is a professional tailor.  

Using previous loans, S. is slowly building his own capital; he is now requesting another loan to enable him to continue building his capital because he will be able to make repayments on a monthly basis, allowing him to increase his income.

loans.use: To build capital to allow him to avoid purchasing on credit and start realizing a profit.

loans.name: Celia

texts.es:
Celia is a member of the comunal bank “Virgen de la Natividad”, which is located on Próceres de la Independencia street, in the district of Callería, in the department of Ucayali. She is 39 years old and is the mother of 2 minor children. She is married and her husband works as a security guard. With the first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to start a business buying chickens and selling their meat.

She currently has a market stall (Number 38) in the Bellavista market, where she sells chicken. She rises at 1:00am to go buy the chickens whose meat she will later sell. In the afternoon, she takes care of her family and goes to bed early so she can begin work again the next day.

With this loan, which she will pay back in 5 months, she will buy more chickens in order to increase her sale.

Celia is very content because she started with few chickens and, thanks to Manuela Ramos, her business has been growing. She has more customers and is able to increase her loan amounts. She now enjoys the economic stability she has always hoped to attain for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Celia pertenece al banco comunal Virgen de la Natividad, el cual está ubicado en Jr. Las Margaritas Mz. 11 Lote 15 AA.HH. Próceres de la Independencia, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 39 años de edad y es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad, es casada y su esposo trabaja como agente de seguridad. Celia con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la compra y venta de pollos.

En la actualidad cuenta con un puesto de venta de pollos en el mercado de Bellavista (puesto Nº 38). Se levantan a la 1.00 a.m. para salir a comprar el pollo para la venta, por las tardes atiende a su familia y descansa temprano para el trajín del día siguiente.

Con este préstamo, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará más pollos para aumentar sus ventas .

Celia está muy contenta porque empezó con pocos pollos y gracias al apoyo de Manuela Ramos su negocio ha ido creciendo, tiene mas clientes y con ello podrá aumentar su crédito. Ahora goza de una estabilidad económica que tanto anhelaba para su familia.

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Cetty

texts.es:
Mrs Cetty belongs to the Community Bank Cesar Vallejo, located at Jr. Bolognesi #199, in the district of Calleria, department of Ucayali.

Cetty is 49 years old, she is separated from her husband and has 8 children, 5 of which are already self-sufficient and 3 that still depend on her.

Cetty received a first loan of 300 S (100USD) from the non-profit association “Manuela Ramos”. She invested this money on a small groceries store, which is nowadays very well supplied.

Cetty wakes up every morning at 6am to prepare her children’s breakfast; at 8am she starts working at the groceries store and she finishes at 8pm.

She would like to receive a loan of 2000 S (700USD) that she will repay in 5 months. With this money, she will buy 1 bag of rice, 1 bag of sugar, 2 boxes of eggs, 1 box of milk, 2 boxes of jello, 1 pack of yoghurt, 2 banana branches, fish and chicken.

Cetty is a very hard working woman and even though she does not have the support from her couple, she does not think this is a handicap to succeed.

Thanks to the loan she received from “Manuela Ramos” she could start her own business and show that she could move up in life and contribute to the education of her children and the wellbeing of all her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Cetty pertenece al banco comunal Cesar Vallejo, ubicado en Jr. Bolognesi 199, distrito D. Calleria, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 49 años, es separda y madre D. 8 hijos, cinco ya son independientes y tres aún dependen D. ella. Cetty con el primer préstamo D. S/. 300 que recibió D. Manuela Ramos deciD. invertir en una pequeña bodega. En la actualidad ella cuenta con una bodega surtida, se levanta a las 6 a.m. para preparar el desayuno D. sus hijos y luego atender su bodega hasta las 8 p.m. Con el préstamo D. S/. 2,000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra D. 1 saco D. arroz, 1 saco D. azúcar, 2 cajas D. huevo, 1 caja D. leche, 2 cajas D. gelatinas, 1 paquete D. yogurt, golosinas, 2 racimos D. plátanos, pescado y pollos. Cetty es una mujer muy trabajadora y a pesar que no cuenta con el apoyo D. su pareja no es impedimento para salir adelante. Gracias al apoyo D. Manuela Ramos ella pudo emprender su propio negocio y demostrar que si pueD. salir adelante para apoyar en la educación D. sus hijos y el bienestar D. toda su familia.

loans.use: To buy groceries (sugar, rice, eggs, milk, jello, yoghurt, bananas, fish and chicken) to supply her groceries store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fabric, thread, elastic, etc.

loans.name: Eldith

texts.es:
Eldith belongs to the Cesar Vallejo communal bank, situated in 141 Jr. Bolognesi, in the Calleria district in Ucayali. She is 47 years old, separated and is the mother of three children; two are independent, and one still depends on her. With the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for S/. 300, Eldith decided to invest in opening a sewing workshop.

Currently, she has the workshop in her home, for which she gets up at 6 a.m., prepares breakfast for her children, and then sews the garments that her clients order daily.

With the loan of S/. 1,000, which she will repay in 5 months, she will invest it in the purchase of fabric, laces, threads, elastics, buttons, zippers, etc.

Eldith, despite not having the support of her partner, was able to move forth and overcome the adversities that were in her path, and bring up her children successfully, who are her adoration. Eldith was able to manage her business satisfactorily thanks to the support she received from Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Eldith pertenece al banco comunal Cesar Vallejo, ubicado en Jr. Bolognesi 141, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 47 años, es separada y madre de 3 hijos, dos independientes y uno aún depende de ella. Eldith con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en un taller de costura.

En la actualidad cuenta con un taller de costura en su hogar, para ello se levanta a las 6 a.m., prepara el desayuno de sus hijos y luego se dedica a coser las prendas que le encargan sus clientes a diario.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de telas, blondas, hilos, elásticos, botones, cierres, etc.

Eldith, a pesar que no cuenta con el apoyo de su pareja, pudo salir adelante y vencer las adversidades que se le presentaban y así sacar adelante a sus hijos que son su adoración. Pudo manejar satisfactoriamente su negocio gracias al apoyo de que le brindó Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics, lace, threads, elastic, buttons, zippers, etc.

loans.name: Esna Nicida

texts.es:
Esna belongs to the Virgen de la Natividad communal bank, situated in Jr. Alfonso Ugarte, Block 7 in the Calleria district in Ucayali. She is 40 years old, married and is the mother of 2 young girls. Her husband sells “brosthers” chickens. With the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for S/. 200, she decided to invest it in the buying and selling of groceries retail.

Currently, she has a stand where she sells groceries in the Bellavista market. She wakes up at 4 a.m. to start her responsibilities in the business and finishes at 6 p.m. She then heads home to tend to her daughters and rest for the following day.

With the loan of S/. 2,300, which she will repay in 5 months, she will purchase 3 cases of milk, 5 sacks of rice, 25 sausages, 10 boxes of chocolates, 10 cases of oil, 2 boxes of eggs, etc.

Esna is very happy because she started with very few products, and her business is currently stocked thanks to the support from Manuela Ramos and also the unconditional support from her family.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Esna pertenece al banco comunal Virgen de la Natividad, ubicado en Jr. Alfonso Ugarte Cuadra 7, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 40 años, es casada y madre de 2 hijas menores de edad, su esposo se dedica a la venta de pollos brosthers. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 200 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la compra y venta de abarrotes al por menor.

En la actualidad cuenta con un puesto de venta de abarrotes en el mercado de Bellavista (puesto Nº 9). Se levanta a las 4.00 a.m. para iniciar sus actividades en el negocio y termina a las 6.00 p.m., luego se dirige a su hogar par atender a sus hijas y descansar para el día siguiente.

Con el préstamo de S/. 2,300, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 3 cajas de leche, 5 cajas de panteones, 5 sacos de arroz, 25 salchichas, 10 cajas de chocolates, 10 cajas de aceite, 2 cajas de huevos, etc.

Esna está muy contenta porque se inició con pocos productos y actualmente ha surtido su negocio gracias al apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos y también al apoyo incondicional de su familia.

loans.use: Purchase groceries (milk, rice, sausages, chocolates, oil, eggs, etc.)

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes belongs to the Virgen de la Natividad communal bank, situated in Jr. Gonzáles Prada Nº 148 in the Callería district in Ucayali. She is 50 years old, and is the mother of a teenage son. Her husband is a chauffeur. Mercedes, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for S/. 300, decided to invest in a small grocery store.

She currently runs her own grocery store. Mercedes wakes up at 6 a.m. to go to the market, prepare breakfast for her son and husband, and then open up her store and tend to her clients.

With the loan of S/. 2,000, which she will repay in 5 months, she will purchase 10 cases of soda pop, 1 sack of rice, 1 sack of sugar, 1 package of oil, 1 case of milk, 1 package of noodles, 2 boxes of eggs, etc.

Mercedes is very happy because the business has been going well ever since she started, and she is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for being a great help for her inversion and the well-being of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Mercedes pertenece al Banco Comunal Virgen de la Natividad, ubicado en Jr. Gonzáles Prada Nº 148, distrito de Callería, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 50 años y es madre de un hijo adolescente, su esposo es chofer. Mercedes con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en una pequeña bodega.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con una bodega. Mercedes se levanta a las 6.00 a.m. para ir al mercado, preparar el desayuno de su hijo y su esposo y luego abrir su bodega para la atención de sus clientes.

Con el préstamo de S/. 2,000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 10 cajas de gaseosas, 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 1 paquete de aceite, 1 caja de leche, 1 paquete de fideos, 2 cajas de huevos, etc.

Mercedes está muy feliz porque desde que empezó con el negocio le va muy bien, y además está muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos porque es una gran ayuda para su inversión y para el bienestar de su familia.

loans.use: Purchase groceries (soda pop, rice, sugar, oil, milk, noodles, eggs, etc.)

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes belongs to the Virgen de la Natividad communal bank, situated in the corner of Jr. Revolución and San Martín Nº 520 in the Calleria district in Ucayali. She is 54 years old, and is the mother of 5 children, all independent. Her husband is a teacher. Mercedes, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for S/. 300, decided to invest in the sale of prepared meals.

Currently, she sells breakfasts and lunches in her front porch. She wakes up at 4 a.m. to go to the market to buy the provisions that she will need to prepare her meals. At 6 a.m., she is ready to tend to her clients who love her flavoring. In the afternoon she rests so that she can be energized for the following day.

With the loan of S/. 1,500, which she will repay in 5 months, she will purchase 1 sack of rice, 1 sack of sugar, 1 case of oil, 1 case of milk, vegetables, fruits, etc.

Mercedes is very happy, and she feels great because the meals she prepares have a strong following. She is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for all the support.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Mercedes pertenece al banco comunal Virgen de la Natividad, ubicado en esquina del Jr. Revolución con San Martín Nº 520, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 54 años y es madre de 5 hijos, todos independientes, su esposo es profesor. Mercedes con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la venta de comida.

En la actualidad vende desayunos y almuerzos en la puerta de su domicilio. Se levantan a las 4.00 a.m. para ir al mercado a comprar sus víveres que va a necesitar para la preparación de sus comidas, a las 6.00 a.m. está lista para atender a sus clientes que gustan mucho de su sazón y en las tarde ella descansa para tener energías para el día siguiente.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,500, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 1 caja de aceite, 1 caja de leche, verduras, frutas, etc.

Mercedes está muy feliz, se siente muy bien porque la comida que prepara tiene mucha acogida y está muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos por todo el apoyo .

loans.use: Purchase of provisions to prepare her meals.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes belongs to the Virgen de la Natividad communal bank, situated in Jr. Revolución con San Martín Nº 520 in the Calleria district in Ucayali. She is 54 years old, and is the mother of 5 children, all independent. Her husband is a teacher. Mercedes, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for S/. 300, decided to invest in the sale of prepared meals.

Currently, she sells breakfasts and lunches in her front porch. She wakes up at 4 a.m. to go to the market to buy the provisions that she will need to prepare her meals. At 6 a.m., she is ready to tend to her clients who love her flavoring. In the afternoon she rests so that she can be energized for the following day.

With the loan of S/. 1,500, which she will repay in 5 months, she will purchase 1 sack of rice, 1 sack of sugar, 1 case of oil, 1 case of milk, vegetables, fruits, etc.

Mercedes is very happy, and she feels great because the meals she prepares have a strong following. She is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for all the support.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Mercedes pertenece al banco comunal Virgen de la Natividad, ubicado en esquina del Jr. Revolución con San Martín Nº 520, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 54 años y es madre de 5 hijos, todos independientes, su esposo es profesor. Mercedes con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la venta de comida.

En la actualidad vende desayunos y almuerzos en la puerta de su domicilio. Se levantan a las 4.00 a.m. para ir al mercado a comprar sus víveres que va a necesitar para la preparación de sus comidas, a las 6.00 a.m. está lista para atender a sus clientes que gustan mucho de su sazón y en las tarde ella descansa para tener energías para el día siguiente.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,500, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 1 caja de aceite, 1 caja de leche, verduras, frutas, etc.

Mercedes está muy feliz, se siente muy bien porque la comida que prepara tiene mucha acogida y está muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos por todo el apoyo .

loans.use: Purchase of provisions to prepare her meals.

loans.name: Nolia

texts.es:
Señora Nolia belongs to the "Virgen de la Natividad" (Virgin of the Nativity) communal bank, which is located at 236 Jr. Sinchi Roca in the Callería district in the department of Ucayali. She is 28-years-old and is the mother of 1 young son. Her husband is a veterinarian. With her first loan of 300 nuevos soles that she received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to invest in a small grocery store in her home.

She gets up at 6:00 a.m. to do her housework and to simultaneously attend to her store until 9:00 p.m., when she rests for the following day.

With this loan of 2,000 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 5 months, she will buy 2 sacks of rice, 2 sacks of sugar, 4 boxes of oil, 2 boxes of milk, 2 containers of eggs, etc.

Nolia is happy. At first, her business was a little difficult, but little by little, she started to have clients and everything changed as time went by. Now her sales are stable and grow every day. Things are changing for her well-being and that of her family, and she is also very thankful to Manuela Ramos for all of the support they have given to her business.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Nolia pertenece al banco comunal Virgen de la Natividad, ubicado en Jr. Sinchi Roca Nº 236, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 28 años y es madre de 1 hijo menor de edad, su esposo es Medico Veterinario. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en una pequeña bodega en su domicilio.

En la actualidad cuenta con una bodega. Se levanta a las 6.00 a.m. para realizar sus actividades en la casa y simultáneamente atiende en su bodega hasta las 9 p.m., luego descansa par el siguiente día.

Con el préstamo de S/. 2,000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 2 sacos de arroz, 2 sacos de azúcar, 4 cajas de aceite, 2 cajas de leche, verduras, 2 casilleros de huevos, etc.

Nolia está muy feliz. Al principio el negocio era un poquito difícil, pero poco a poco empezó a tener clientes y todo fue cambiando con el paso del tiempo. Ahora su venta está estable y crece cada día. Las cosas van cambiando para su bien y el de su familia y además está muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos por todo el apoyo dado para su negocio.

loans.use: To purchase groceries (sugar, rice, oil, etc.)

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Ms. Norma belongs to the communal bank “Virgen de la Natividad”, located in Peru Nº 597, district of Callería, department of Ucayali. She is 44 years old and she is a mother of 2 children, the youngest still depends on her. Her husband is a civil servant. With the first loan of $100 that she obtained from “Manuela Ramos Microfinancing”, she decided to invest in a small beauty salon at home. Every day, she gets up at 6:00 a.m. to go to the market and to prepare breakfast for her children and husband, then she prepares lunch and later she works at her beauty salon with a lot of dedication. She will buy 2 big bottles of liquids for perms, different hair coloring, lacquers, caps to make highlights, etc with the loan of $850 that will repay in 5 months. Norma is very happy since her business is doing well thanks to god and to the support of Manuela Ramos Microfinancing.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Norma pertenece al banco comunal Virgen de la Natividad, ubicado en Jr. Perú Nº 597, distrito de Callería, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 44 años y es madre de 2 hijos, uno mayor de edad y un menor que aún depende de ella. Su esposo es empleado público. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en un pequeño salón de belleza en su domicilio. Se levanta a las 6.00 a.m. para ir al mercado y preparar el desayuno de sus hijos y su esposo, luego prepara el almuerzo y después atiende su estética con esmero y dedicación. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,500, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 2 botellas grandes de líquidos para peinados permanentes, tintes de diversos colores, lacas, gorros para realizar rayitos, bolondon, etc. Norma está muy feliz pues manifiesta que su negocio le va muy bien gracias a dios y al apoyo que Manuela Ramos le brinda. Su negocio tiene cada vez mas acogida entre sus clientes por el servicio que brinda.

loans.use: Buy supplies for a beauty salon

loans.name: Sofia

texts.es:
Sofía belongs to the communal bank Virgen de la Natividad, located in Jr. Maya de Brito cuadra 2, Callería district, Ucayali state. She is 40 years old and is mother to one son, her husband is a mechanic. With the first loan for S/300 that she received from Manuela Ramos she decided to invest in a small grocery stand in the market.

Today she still has her grocery stand. She gets up at 4:00 am to go to work and open her business very early as the majority of her sales are in the early morning hours in the market. In the afternoons she rests and spends time with her family.

With a loan for S/1500, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will buy 2 sacks of rice, 2 sacks of sugar, 1 case of oil, 1 case of milk, 1 case of noodles, 2 boxes of eggs, 4 boxes of cakes, 4 cases of milk, 10 boxes of chocolate, etc.

Things are going well for Sofia, her business is growing and she feels very content because she is able to support her household and provide happiness to her beloved family members. In addition she is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for the great help that it provides to her.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Sofía pertenece al banco comunal Virgen de la Natividad, ubicado en Jr. Maya de Brito cuadra 2, distrito de Callería, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 40 años y es madre de un hijo, su esposo es mecánico. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300 que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en un pequeño puesto de venta de abarrotes en el mercado.

En la actualidad cuenta con un puesto de venta de abarrotes. Se levanta a las 4.00 a.m. para ir a trabajar y abrir su negocio muy temprano ya que la mayor venta se da a tempranas horas en el mercado y en las tardes se dedica a descansar y pasar buenos momentos con su familia.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,500, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará 2 sacos de arroz, 2 sacos de azúcar, 1 paquete de aceite, 1 caja de leche, 1 paquete de fideos, 2 cajas de huevos, 4 cajas de panetón, 4 cajas de leche, 10 cajas de chocolate, etc.

A Sofía le va muy bien, ahora su negocio está creciendo y se siente muy contenta porque le permite aportar en su hogar y dar felicidad a sus seres queridos y además está muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos por la gran ayuda que le brinda.

loans.use: Purchase groceries (sugar, rice, oil, milk, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more merchandise for her little cosmetics business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more fruit for re-sale and help his wife's business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Diversify her merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of clothing for the beach

loans.name: Luis Enrique

texts.es:
Mr. Luis S. is single and comes from the City of Chontales. He moved to Managua in search of a better life. He started working in the sale of cosmetics since he was very young. First he had a cart in the local market, Mercado Oriental de Managua, then later on - and due to his hard work and determination- he was able to buy a stand (booth) at the market where he continued to sell cosmetics. Currently Mr. S. has two stands at the market. His aspiration is to continue to grow. He will use the loan to buy new products that are constantly coming out on the market.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Don Luis S. es soltero, originario de la Ciudad de Chontales, pero en busca de una mejor vida se fue a vivir a la ciudad de Managua. Desde muy joven empezó a trabajar en la venta de cosméticos, empezó vendiendo cosméticos en una carreta en el mercado Oriental de Managua, pero gracias al empeño de salir adelante, tiempo después logró comprar un tramo en el mercado donde tambien siguió con las ventas de cosméticos, hoy en día don Luis tiene dos tramos en el mercado. Sus aspiraciones son seguir creciendo más, quiere el crédito para comprar nuevos productos que constantemente salen al mercado.

loans.use: Buy Shampoos, Lotions and Cosmetics

loans.name: Azucena De Los Angel

texts.es:
Miss Azucena lives in the neighborhood of Villa Reconciliación de Managua. A few years ago Miss Azucena was a stay at home mother and homemaker but eventually decided to help her husband support the family. She started selling sweets, juices and sodas out of her home. As time went by she grew her business and at the present time she has a small general store where she sells a variety of products used in everyday life.

She needs the loan in order to keep investing in her business and to continue expanding since she wishes to, one day, have a grocery store.

Translated from the Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Azucena Pérez habita en el barrio Villa Reconciliación de Managua. Hace años atrás doña Azucena se dedicaba al cuido de sus hijos y su hogar, pero decidió darle apoyo a su marido en los gastos de la casa, es por eso que decidió empezar con un pequeño negocio en su casa, ventas de confites, jugos y gaseosas, pero con el pasar del tiempo decidió hacer crecer su negocio y desde ese entonces lo ha venido haciendo crecer más, actualmente tiene una pulpería y oferta variedad de productos del consumo diario en los hogares. Necesita el prestamo para seguir inviertiendo en su negocio y hacerlo crecer más porque quiere llegar a tener una miscelánea

loans.use: To buy grains and perishable goods

loans.name: Edelmira

texts.es:
Early in 2003, because of her family, Edelmira decided to start a business selling tacos in a cart outside of her house so that she can help her family because her household was going through a financial crisis. During the day she would study, and at night she would set up her taco stand. Little by little she acquired customers until she managed to get an established locale. A year ago she had a son, to whom she would like to offer the best so he can have more opportunities in life. Currently she has two employees who help her in the business because she cannot tend to it by herself.

However, Edelmira would like to keep growing because there is a high demand for her tacos. This is why she is requesting a loan for US $750, which she is willing to pay in a period of 6 months. With this money Edelmira will be able to buy two griddles to make tacos quicker. With your help Edelmira will be able to support her child.

In the photos Edelmira is in the kitchen, in front of her is one griddle where they make tacos and behind her a table where they prepare them and the refrigerator.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

A inicios del 2003, debido a que su familia, Edelmira decidió poner un negocio de venta de tacos en un carrito fuera de su casa. Para así poder ayudarle a su familia puesto que en su casa pasaban por una crisis económica. Durante el día se iba a estudiar y por las noches ponía el puesto de tacos. Poco a poco se fue haciendo de clientes hasta que pudo hacerse de un local establecido. Hace un año que tuvo un hijo al cual desea darle lo mejor para que pueda tener más oportunidades. Actualmente tiene dos empleados que le ayudan en su negocio puesto que ella no puede atenderlo sola.

Sin embargo Edelmira desea seguir creciendo puesto que la demanda que tiene es buena. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $750 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Edelmira podrá comprar dos parrillas para poder hacer mas rápido los tacos. Con tu ayuda Edelmira podrá sacar adelante a su hijo. Dentro de la fotos Eelmira se encuentra en la cocina frente a ella está una parrilla donde hacen los tacos y tras de ella está una mesa en dónde se preparan y el refrigerador.

loans.use: Buying two griddles to prepare tacos (Comprar dos parrillas para elaborar los tacos)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more wood and other furniture making materials

loans.name: San Miguel De Mayocc Group

texts.en:
“San Miguel D. Mayocc” is a small rural community bank of FINCA Peru’s Wari project, which provides credit with education services in the rural areas of Huancavelica. Huancavelica is considered one of the poorest regions of Peru and has many limitations, being a very mountainous area (altituD. ranges from 6,000 – 17,000 ft above sea level), the cold, the difficulty of growing crops and the lack of an adequate infrastructure of roads and communication systems.

BCR “San Miguel D. Mayocc” is located in the district with the same name as the bank, in the province of Churcampa. The community, situated in one of the lowest parts of the department of Huancavelica, at only 6,500 ft above sea level at the borders of the Mantaro river, has, compared to other parts of the department of Huancavelica, a warm almost tropical climate. The warm climate and the vicinity of the river make the area very suitable for growing fruits like oranges, lemons, avocado, papaya and mango. Besides the fruits, most of the people dedicate their time raising guinea-pigs, which are considered a delicacy.

The bank was formed recently with 13 female borrowers and therefO. has no history…yet. It has only just started to create history in its community. The expectations working with FINCA Peru are very clear: increase business and save. For all members, the main use of the savings they will be generating is to invest in their business´ or for the education of their children, buying school uniforms, supplies, books and even to pay the fee for entering primary or secondary school.

As mentioned in the introduction, the area is known for guinea-pig raising and for fruit production. With only a few exceptions, the members of the community bank dedicate their time to both activities. Some of the members are investing their loan in new fruit plants, others need the loan for raising the guinea-pigs. Of the exceptions in the group, 2 have a small grocery stO. and another has a “cafetin”, a small kiosk selling sweets, drinks and sandwiches at a school in a neighboring city.

Every member has a different testimony, as is the case of Cristina C. D. M.. Cristina maD. her loan request of 200 soles to be able to buy new fruit plants and fertilizer. Antonia F. D. M., the group´s democratically elected President, has another purpose for her loan of 600 soles: increasing her stO. with mO. supplies like rice, sugar, soft drinks and beer. Alberta A. R., the woman with the smallest loan in the group (with 100 soles), will invest in food for her guinea-pigs. She will buy special food to be able to raise high quality guinea-pigs. The guinea-pigs can be sold in cities nearby: Huanta and Ayacucho.

Although many women dedicate their time to the same business, they require different loan sizes because of the differences in the size of the business they run. The loans range from 100 soles, 200 soles, up to 600 soles and the total of the loans reach 4,300 soles among the 13 members.

loans.use: Leader's loan use: buy more supplies for her store

loans.name: Socorro Guadalupe

texts.es:
"Although I am a sales employee in a business that makes plastic colorings, my salary is not enough", commented Socorro Guadalupe. Socorro is a single mother of two girls, one of her daughters is 15 and the other one 7 years old. Unfortunately the father of these girls does not contribute to his daughters' expenses, and this is why Socorro has a job and in addition has another job in her free time, so that she can make enough money to pay for the household expenses and her daughters' education. In July of 1993, she started selling clothing. Then she helped a neighbor selling perfumes. And starting in 1998, when for one of her daughters' birthday she created some flower arrangements, which were liked by all the guests, and so she was asked to create these products. Little by little, through recommendations of her excellent work, she has become well known in her community.

However, right now she has several orders she needs to make, and she does not have enough money or materials to make all of them. This is why Socorro is requesting a loan for US $650, which she is willing to pay in a period of 5 months. With this money Socorro will be able to cover all the orders she has, and save for school expenses. With your help Socorro will be able to support her daughters.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

“Aunque soy empleada de ventas en una empresa que se dedica a la fabricación de tintas plástica, pero el sueldo que percibo no me es suficiente” Comentó Socorro Guadalupe. Socorro es madre soltera de dos niñas una de 15 y la otra de 7 años, desafortunadamente el padre de las niñas no se quiere hacer cargo de los gastos de sus hijas y es por eso que Socorro tiene un trabajo y en su tiempos libres tiene otro trabajo para poder sacar para pagar los gastos del hogar y los estudios de sus dos hijas. En julio de 1993 comenzó vendiendo ropa, después le ayudó a una vecina a vender productos de perfumería y fue a partir de 1998 que en el cumpleaños de una de sus hijas le hizo unos arreglos que a todas las invitadas les gustó y le pidieron para que les elabore estos productos. Poco a poco y con la recomendación de su buen trabajo a sido que se a hecho reconocida en su comunidad.

Sin embargo actualmente tiene varios pedidos que elaborar, y no cuenta con dinero o material suficiente como para poder hacer todos sus productos .Es por eso que Socorro está solicitando un crédito de US $650 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 5 meses. Con este dinero Socorro podrá cumplir con los pedidos que le hicieron. Y con este dinero poder ahorrar para los gastos escolares. Con tu ayuda Socorro podrá sacar a sus hijas adelante.

loans.use: Buying raw materials (Comprar materia prima)

loans.name: Rosalva

texts.es:
Rosalva is a woman who likes to fight for her dreams. One of her dreams is to see her children going to college and having a greater chance of having a better quality of life than she did. This is why Rosalva started selling furniture three years ago. However, the sales of these type of products are very slow, and this is why she started selling clothing, which is what she does now. Little by little she has assembled a clientele who seeks her out to buy clothing from her.

However, Rosalva does not have enough merchandise to offer to her customers, and this is why she is requesting a loan for US $550, which she is willing to pay in a period of 6 months. With this money Rosalva will be able to buy clothing for the season to be able to offer it to her customers. With your help Rosalva will be able to succeed with her children.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Rosalva es una mujer a la que le gusta luchar por sus sueños. Y uno de ellos es ver que sus hijos puedan estudiar una carrera y tengan mayores probabilidades de tener un mejor nivel de vida. Es por eso que Rosalva comenzó desde hace 3 años a vender muebles pero las ventas de estos productos eran muy lentas, fue por eso que comenzó a vender ropa, a lo que se dedica actualmente. Poco a poco se a ido haciendo de clientela que la busca para comprarle ropa.

Sin embargo Rosalva no cuenta con suficiente mercancía para ofrecerle a sus clientes es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $550 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Rosalva podrá comprar más ropa de temporada para poder ofrecerle a sus clientes. Con tu ayuda Rosalva podrá salir adelante con sus hijos.

loans.use: Buying merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in cleaning products and plastics

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es:
In 2004, Patricia started making and selling crafts after going through a terrible period of time, when she got divorced, which was very hard for her. "I needed money and at the same time I needed to distract myself in something that would keep me busy. So I thought of doing something I really enjoyed and that is how I decided to begin in the business of crafts, and that worked very well for me.", she commented. Currently, she can count on regular customers and she has a group of people to whom she teaches how to make this type of craft.

However, Patricia would like to expand her business and that is why she is requesting a loan for US $925, which she is determined to pay in a period of 6 months. With this money Patricia will be able to buy merchandise to be able to produce more crafts and form more groups to teach. With your help Patricia will be able to move forward from this phase and support her son who is her motivation for all of her efforts.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

En el 2004 Patricia comenzó a hacer y vender manualidades después de tener un terrible episodio. Puesto que se divorció y fue muy difícil para ella. “Necesitaba dinero y a la vez distraerme en algo que me mantuviera ocupada y pensé que tenia que hacer algo que verdaderamente me gustara y fue así como decidí emprender el negocio de las manualidades y me dio resultado” comentó. Actualmente ya cuenta con una cartera de clientes y actualmente tiene un grupo de personas a quienes enseña este tipo de manualidades.

Sin embargo Patricia desea crecer su negocio es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $925 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Patricia podrá comprar mercancía para poder elaborar más productos y/o formar más grupos de enseñanza. Con tu ayuda Patricia podrá superar este episodio y sacar adelante a su hijo quien es su motivación para todo su esfuerzo.

loans.use: Buying materials to produce her crafts (Comprar material para elaborar sus productos)

loans.name: Virgen De Fátima Group

texts.en:
“Virgen D. Fátima” is a rural community bank in FINCA Peru’s Wari project, which provides credit with education services in the rural areas of Huancavelica. Huancavelica is considered one of the poorest regions of Peru and has many limitations, such as being a very mountainous area (altituD. ranges from 6,000 – 17,000 ft above sea level), the cold, the difficulty of growing crops and the lack of an adequate infrastructure of roads and communication systems.

BCR “Virgen D. Fátima” is located in the small community of La Merced in the province of Churcampa, at over 9,000 ft above sea level. Currently the bank has completed 2 loan cycles after just one year of existence. Currently there are 20 female borrowers.

The members of the bank, during their one year in FINCA Peru, besides having learned to be responsible and punctual, have learned to respect each other and to help another member of the group when they face some kind of difficulty. At each bi-weekly reunion a different member of the group prepares a small meal that she will sell for 1 sol (about 35 cents U.S!), and the profit she will add to her savings in the bank.

The group was able to save over 4,900 soles (about 1,600 US$) in the first 2 loan cycles and will continue to save in the future. For all members, the main use of the savings is for investing in their business or for the education of their children. Another dream they have for the use of their savings is to be able to make renovations to their houses, like constructing another floor or changing the roof to a more sustainable material.

Most members of the community bank run the same business: they have fields with corn, wheat and peas. And a little bit lower down at the Mantaro river basin, where it’s a little warmer, they grow fruits like oranges and mango. There is one special fruit they cultivate: the fruit of the tuna-cactus. As all of these product are seasonal, they also have mountain goats and minor animals like chickens and guinea-pigs. Most of the products they sell weekly at the local market of Churcampa or a little further away in Huanta. Two also run grocery stores in the community.

The loans range from 200 soles, 500 soles up to 600 soles and the total of the loans reach 5,100 soles among the 20 members. The amounts of 500 and 600 soles are exceptions.

Although many dedicate their time to the same business, every member has a different testimony, as is the case of Perpetua Murga A.. Perpetua was the woman that formed the bank in its first cycle and was elected the first president. With her 600 soles loan she will buy new supplies for her grocery store. And with her 450 soles of savings she will hire someone to make holes in the ground to put new tara and tuna-cactus plants

Marcelina M. V. will invest her 200 soles buying plants of the tuna-cactus and of tara. Both need time to grow before they get productive (tuna 1 year and tara 3 years). Meanwhile she will depend on her mountain-goats: the sells them for the meat, but also she makes cheese from goat-milk.

loans.use: Buy new inventory for grocery store

loans.name: Martha Alicia

texts.es:
With the goal of supporting her four children and being able to offer them a better future, by offering them the chance to study in university, Martha started looking for a way to obtain an extra income because with what her husband makes as a driver in a lumber yard, it is not enough to pay for their children's school expenses. This is why in October of 2001, Martha Alicia started selling soft drinks and sweets outside of her home. Little by little people started to notice that these type of products were sold in her house, and so she continued to acquire other types of merchandise, such as chips, bread, and so on. After some time, she saved enough money to set up what is now her general store.

However, right now Martha wants to expend her business and this is why she is requesting a loan for US $650, which she is willing to pay in a period of 5 months. "So I can have a better and greater stock of products that allows me to offer proper attention to my customers, so they can always find what they are looking for", she commented. With your help, Martha will be able to increase her business so that all of her children can have the opportunity to go to college.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Con el propósito de sacar a sus 4 hijos adelante, y poderles brindar un mejor futuro, al ofrecerles que estudien una carrera universitaria Martha comenzó a ver la manera de sacar otros ingresos. Puesto que con lo que gana su esposo como chofer de una maderería, no es suficiente como para pagar los gastos de los estudios de sus hijos. Fue por eso que en Octubre del 2001 Martha Alicia comenzó a vender refrescos y dulces fuera de su casa. Poco a poco la gente se fue dando cuenta que en esa casa se vendían este tipo de productos y así fue como siguió adquiriendo otro tipo de mercancía, como botanas, pan, y poco a poco se hizo de mercancía, después juntó un poco de dinero para poder acondicionar la que hoy es su tienda de abarrotes.

Sin embargo Actualmente Martha desea crecer más su empresa es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $650 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 5 meses. “Para poder tener un mejor y mayor surtido de abarrotes que me permita atender debidamente a mis clientes y siempre encuentren lo que buscan” comentó. Con tu ayuda Martha podrá crecer su negocio para que todos sus hijos puedan tener la oportunidad de estudiar una carrera universitaria.

loans.use: Buying merchandise

loans.name: María Cristina

texts.es:
"Because of the need to have an income that would allow me to move forward and become and independent woman, without fear of challenges, and to grow as a person and as a mother doing what I like, which is sales, obtaining an income to support my daughters", commented Maria Cristina. In April of 1996, after becoming a widow, Maria started selling some clothing, then after some time she had a small general store and she sold jewelry and ceramics. Then she opened an office and school supplies store, and four years ago she started selling rustic decorative products. Maria always tried to look for new things to sell in her business, because she needed the money to be able to support her two daughters of 7 and16 years of age.

However, currently Maria has not been able to stock new merchandise because of lack of capital. This is why she is requesting a loan for US $650, which she is determined to pay in 5 months. With this money Maria will be able to buy more merchandise such as vases, flower pots, pictures, fountains, lamps, animal figurines, and so on. With your help Maria Cristina will be able to support her daughters and offer them a college education.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

"Por la necesidad de tener un ingreso que me permitiera salir adelante y de ser una mujer independiente, sin miedo a los retos y trascender como persona y como madre, realizando lo que me gusta que son las ventas y obteniendo un ingreso para sostener a mi hijas”. Comentó María Cristina. En Abril de 1996 después de enviudar María comenzó a vender un poco de ropa, después de un tiempo tuvo una tiendita, y vendía joyería, y cerámica, después abrió una papelería y hace cuatro años comenzó a vender adornos rústicos. María siempre trató de buscar nuevos giros en el negocio. Puesto que necesitaba sacar dinero para poder pagar a sus 2 hijas de 7 y 16 años.

Sin embargo actualmente María no ah podido surtir de nueva mercancía por falta de presupuesto. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $650 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 5 meses y con este dinero María podrá comprar más mercancía como; floreros, macetas, cuadros, fuentes, lámparas, figuras de animales, etc. Con tu ayuda María Cristina podrá sacar a sus hijas adelante y poderles ofrecer educación Universitaria.

loans.use: Buying merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of merchandise.

loans.name: Luz María

texts.es:
Luz is the mother of small children. Her husband is a truck driver who is often on the road and away from home. When he's away, there are sometimes long gaps when he can't send money to cover the children's expenses. Consequently, Luz began helping a cousin sell cosmetics from a catalog with the goal of having an income to cover her family's daily expenses. Later, she decided to start her own business selling cosmetics and shoes bought from catalogs. Little by little, she's been able to build her business. She can now count on a list of customers who seek her out to buy her products.

Since her customers have placed various orders that Luz can't now provide, she's applying for a US$550 loan, to be repaid over 6 months, that she can use to buy new products to offer her customers. With your help, Luz will be able to push her family ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Luz María es madre de unos pequeños. Su esposo es conductor de trailers. Y constantemente se la pasa fuera de la ciudad. Y al andar fuera, en ocaciones tarda mucho en mandarle dinero para los gastosde sus hijos. Es por eso que Luz con el propósito de tener un ingreso que le ayude a cubrir los gastos diarios de sus hijos, comenzó a ayudarle a una prima a vender cosméticos por catálogo, y las ganancias se las dividían. Después de un tiempo se decidió iniciar su propio negocio de venta de cosméticos por catálogo y a este negocio le agregó la venta de zapatos por catálogo. Poco a poco Luz a podido crecer su negocio. Actualmente ya cuenta con una cartera de clientes que la buscan para comprarle sus productos.

Sin embargo sus clientes le hicieron varios pedidos que Luz no a podido surtir, es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $550 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Luz podrá comprar productos nuevos para poder tener ofertas nuevas para sus clientes. Con tu ayuda Luz podrá sacar adelante a su familia.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy a cooler

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in clothes for the warm weather season

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more merchandise

loans.name: Laila Yvonne

texts.es:
Marzo de 1989, cuando Laila aún no estaba casada comenzó a vender cosméticos de reconocidas marcas y ropa entre amistades y familiares, ya que en su casa no contaban con suficiente dinero para poder mantenerla. Después se casó y dejó el negocio, después de que sus hijos comenzaron a crecer y con lo que gana su esposo no les alcanza para pagar todos los gastos que les piden en la escuela de sus hijos. En el 2002 reinició sus ventas pero ahora vendiendo pollos rostizados los fines de semana y tortas y tacos durante la semana. Poco a poco se a ido haciendo conocida en su comunidad.

Sin embargo Laila está solicitando un crédito de US $550 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 5 meses con este dinero Laila podrá comprar material como; carne, pan, tortillas, masa, verduras, desechables, condimentos, aderezos, así como enseres menores tales como platos, sartenes, cuchillos, comales, etc. Con tu ayuda Laila podrá salir adelante y ayudar a su esposo a que sus 2 hijos salgan adelante con los estudios.

loans.use: Comprar materia prima para elaborar los pollos rostizados

loans.name: Laila Yvonne

texts.es:
In March, 1989, before Laila was married, she began selling well-known brands of cosmetics and clothing to her friends and family because there wasn't enough money to cover expenses at home. She later married and left the business, but once her children began growing, she was faced with paying school expenses that her husband's earnings couldn't cover. In 2002, she turned again to sales but this time selling roast chickens on weekends and cakes and tacos during the week. Little by little, she's built a following in the neighborhood.

Now Laila is asking for a US$550 loan, to be repaid in 5 months, with which she can buy ingredients like meat, bread, tortillas, pastry dough, green vegetables, condiments, seasoning, etc., along with things like dishes, pans, spoons, "comales" (a traditional griddle for making tortillas), etc. With your help, Laila will be able to improve her business and help her husband pay their 2 children's school expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman

Marzo de 1989, cuando Laila aún no estaba casada comenzó a vender cosméticos de reconocidas marcas y ropa entre amistades y familiares, ya que en su casa no contaban con suficiente dinero para poder mantenerla. Después se casó y dejó el negocio, después de que sus hijos comenzaron a crecer y con lo que gana su esposo no les alcanza para pagar todos los gastos que les piden en la escuela de sus hijos. En el 2002 reinició sus ventas pero ahora vendiendo pollos rostizados los fines de semana y tortas y tacos durante la semana. Poco a poco se a ido haciendo conocida en su comunidad.

Sin embargo Laila está solicitando un crédito de US $550 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 5 meses con este dinero Laila podrá comprar material como; carne, pan, tortillas, masa, verduras, desechables, condimentos, aderezos, así como enseres menores tales como platos, sartenes, cuchillos, comales, etc. Con tu ayuda Laila podrá salir adelante y ayudar a su esposo a que sus 2 hijos salgan adelante con los estudios.

loans.use: Buy ingredients for food business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy merchandise for the upcoming season

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Make improvements to his restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in merchandise

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
Yolanda is the mother of 5 children, all grown and married. Thanks to Yolanda's efforts, all of her children went as far in school as they were able. Seven years ago, Yolanda began working, buying and selling various products, and three years ago, on a friend's recommendation, she began selling cosmetics from a catalog. Little by little, she's built up a customer base in her neighborhood.

Filling orders takes up to 20 days because Yolanda has to wait for any products that she doesn't already have to be delivered to her. She's applying for a US$525 loan, which she's confident she can repay in 6 months, so that she can buy products to keep her customers happy and ensure they continue buying from her. She also wants to use the loan to be able to buy some extra things for a raffle among her neighbors. With your help, Yolanda will be able to push her family ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Yolanda S. es madre de 5 hijos, todos ya grandes y casados. Gracias al esfuerzo de Yolanda cada hijo estudió hasta donde se pudo. Hace 7 años que Yolanda comenzó a trabajar, comprando y vendiendo varios productos, sin embargo después una amiga de ella le recomendó vender cosméticos por catálogo hace tres años. Y desde entonces que vende estos productos. Poco a poco se está haciendo conocida en su comunidad.

Sin embargo para que le entreguen los pedidos a Yolanda se tardan 20 días y ella ya tiene unas cosas que sus clientes le pidieron, es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $525 este dinero Yolanda está segura que lo podrá pagar en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Yolanda podrá comprar más productos para que sus clientes se sientan a gusto con Yolanda y le sigan comprando. Además de que con este dinero Yolanda podrá comprar unas cosas extras para hacer rifas entre sus vecinos. Con tu ayuda Yolanda podrá sacar adelante a su familia.

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: Ana Lucía

texts.es:
Ana Lucia is married and the mother of 4 children. One, a daughter, is married. Two others of the children work and live with her and the youngest is still in school. Three years ago, Ana Lucia began selling shoes from catalogs. She formed a group of customers who order shoes from her and pay for them collectively rather than individually. That way, she's able to offer her customers a way to buy the products on credit.

Ana Lucia sees an opportunity to buy shoes that, because of the time of year, are on sale. She's applying for a US$475 loan, to be repaid in 6 months, with which she can buy the shoes on sale and, in turn, sell to her customers at a lower price. With your help, Ana Lucia will be able to move her family ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Ana Lucía, es esposa y madre de 4 hijos. Los cuales una mujer está casada, dos más viven con ella y están trabajando y el más pequeño estudia la secundaria. Hace 3 años que Ana Lucía comenzó a vender zapatos por catálogo. Además de formar un grupo de clientes que le piden zapatos y van haciendo pagos en plazos de los mismos (tanda). Para así poderles dar la facilidad a sus clientes de comprar un artículo a crédito.

Sin embargo Ana Lucía quiere aprovechar que en esta temporada los zapatos están en oferta.
